update.description: I implemented minibatch training in the Segway trunk, where each training iteration uses a random subset of the include_coords windows rather than all of them.  Minibatch training allows training to touch every position in the genome while maintaining fast iterations.  It is controlled with the --minibatch-num-windows option.  It selects random windows from --include-coords, so you want to use the full genome for --include-coords.  Likelihood-based stopping criterion is no longer valid with minibatch training, so I made it so that it always to max-train-rounds if --minibatch-num-windows is set.
update.title: Minibatch training

content.raw: Changes integrated. @ericr86, please review and merge.
content.html: Changes integrated. @ericr86, please review and merge.

content.raw: As defined around run.py:1964, this patch changes the loadAccRange parameter from a range ("0:N") to a comma-delimited list ("0,1,...").  GMTK parses a range of "0:4" into the list "0,1,2,3,4". The order is not important.
content.html: As defined around run.py:1964, this patch changes the loadAccRange parameter from a range ("0:N") to a comma-delimited list ("0,1,..."). GMTK parses a range of "0:4" into the list "0,1,2,3,4". The order is not important.

content.raw:
@mlibbrecht I've ran more tests and specifically when I ran into a test with mulitple windows, specifically the "mulitpledatasets" test I found a discrepancy in `loadAccRange` again and I'm not sure if the changes are equivalent.

Namely this change produces this for gmtkEMTrain:

`-loadAccRange 1,0` 

Before it was this:

`-loadAccRange 0:1`

These do not *look* equivalent but it might be something GMTK-specific that I'm unaware of. I'm also not sure if ordering is important in this case.
content.html:
@mlibbrecht I've ran more tests and specifically when I ran into a test with mulitple windows, specifically the "mulitpledatasets" test I found a discrepancy in loadAccRange again and I'm not sure if the changes are equivalent.

-loadAccRange 1,0

Before it was this:

-loadAccRange 0:1

These do not look equivalent but it might be something GMTK-specific that I'm unaware of. I'm also not sure if ordering is important in this case.

update.description: I implemented minibatch training in the Segway trunk, where each training iteration uses a random subset of the include_coords windows rather than all of them.  Minibatch training allows training to touch every position in the genome while maintaining fast iterations.  It is controlled with the --minibatch-num-windows option.  It selects random windows from --include-coords, so you want to use the full genome for --include-coords. update.title: Minibatch training

content.raw:
@mlibbrecht, thanks for this addition. I think it will be very useful. The implementation looks fine but I am concerned about the interface--it's not totally friendly to have to set number of windows and `--split-sequences` like that, I'm not sure how it interacts with windows that are less than the max (say at the end of a chromosome or an `--include-coords` region and I think we are going to have some confused users.

What would you think instead of having the interface like `--minibatch-fraction=FRAC` instead. `FRAC` would be a number between 0.0 and 1.0 indicating how much of the selected training region (default: the whole genome). You would store that integer number of bases in a variable. Then you would keep adding random windows until you got to that fraction of the genome, rather than just a particular number of windows. Making sure to compare against integer number of bases would reduce any numerical problems you might get from comparing with fractions that might lead to never getting to 1.0.
content.html:
@mlibbrecht, thanks for this addition. I think it will be very useful. The implementation looks fine but I am concerned about the interface--it's not totally friendly to have to set number of windows and --split-sequences like that, I'm not sure how it interacts with windows that are less than the max (say at the end of a chromosome or an --include-coords region and I think we are going to have some confused users.

What would you think instead of having the interface like --minibatch-fraction=FRAC instead. FRAC would be a number between 0.0 and 1.0 indicating how much of the selected training region (default: the whole genome). You would store that integer number of bases in a variable. Then you would keep adding random windows until you got to that fraction of the genome, rather than just a particular number of windows. Making sure to compare against integer number of bases would reduce any numerical problems you might get from comparing with fractions that might lead to never getting to 1.0.

content.raw: It's not guaranteed to touch *every* genomic position but it will cover much more of the genome than using the same, say, 1% over and over again.
content.html: It's not guaranteed to touch every genomic position but it will cover much more of the genome than using the same, say, 1% over and over again.

content.raw: There are two ways of specifying a list to GMTK: a range such as "3:8", or a comma-delimited list such as "3,4,5,6,7".  When `self.minibatch_num_windows` is 1, `train_windows` is `"0,1,2,...,last_window"`.
